text: I believe that a language feature called “algebraic effects and handlers”, because of their overwhelming simplicity, is a key to make programming more accessible to people. Please read my article about it. <https://github.com/Hihaheho/Desk/blob/main/docs/blog/0002-algebraic-effects.md|https://github.com/Hihaheho/Desk/blob/main/docs/blog/0002-algebraic-effects.md>

elements.text: I believe that a language feature called “algebraic effects and handlers”, because of their overwhelming simplicity, is a key to make programming more accessible to people. Please read my article about it.

text:
One more software system designed to be minimalist: <https://minimacy.net/>
There are many ways to be minimalist because there are so many criteria that can be minimized. This one aims for minimal total code complexity within the constraints of being useable for a specific category of code, which is roughly a single server or desktop process. Minimacy is a programming language (strongly resembling the ML family) plus a virtual machine that runs the compiled code. The VM can run on bare metal, or as a process in a host OS. Development happens outside the system. The whole system wants to remain undertstandable in all detail by a single person. So far that's guaranteed by having a single author.
I attended a seminar by it author yesterday, where he discussed many of the tradeoffs made. Sounded quite reasonable.

attachments.fallback: An open-source minimalist computing technology based on the principle “Less is more”
attachments.text: Why minimalist? Because at Minimacy we consider that the way software is developed today brings too much complexity and opacity while we need simplicity and transparency if we want to achieve security, sustainability and sovereignty.
attachments.title: An open-source minimalist computing technology based on the principle “Less is more”
